xml.name: Quick-fixes and Intentions
xml.Text: shows all the same fix-its for your Swift code as Xcode does.
xml.Try: Press ShowIntentionActions and select Apply Fix-it to replace the unused variable with _

AppCode also integrates SourceKit as a separate inspection. This means you can run it on the whole file and fix all the problems at once if several fix-its are available. Press CodeInspection.OnEditor.
xml.Text: As you can see, we have three problems in this piece of code: two warnings and one error. Select Swift â†’ SourceKit inspections, press ShowIntentionActions and select Apply Fix-it (or click the Apply Fix-it button on the right). This should correct all three problems.
xml.Try: Now press EditorEscape to return to the editor window, place the caret on the incorrectly spelled variable name, and then press ShowIntentionActions. Select Type: Rename to..., choose the correct option, and then press EditorEnter
Note how only the needed part was corrected and all variable usages were automatically renamed. Now, repeat the same actions twice to fix the incorrctlySpeled string.
Press GotoNextError to go to the next error.
Error handling intentions can help you add try/catch/throws where needed. Press ShowIntentionActions and select one of the quick-fixes.
Press GotoNextError to go to the next warning.
You can also remove redundant @objc attributes. Press ShowIntentionActions and select Remove redundant attribute @objc.
If you need to add or remove an explicit type to/from some variable, simply press ShowIntentionActions and select Add/Remove explicit type. Try it now with the fileManager variable.
